Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Ultrasound-Guided Erector Spinae Plane Block and Quadratus Lumborum Block for Analgesia in Laparoscopic Nephrectomy

Background: This study aimed to directly compare the analgesic effectiveness and recovery benefits of ultrasound-guided erector spinae plane block (ESPB) versus quadratus lumborum block (QLB) in patients undergoing laparoscopic nephrectomy.

Methods: In this single-center, double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 54 patients aged 18–70 years with ASA grades I–II were recruited from Sichuan Provincial People’s Hospital between August 16, 2023, and October 30, 2023. Participants were randomised 1:1 to receive either ESPB or QLB with 25 mL of 0.4% ropivacaine. The primary outcome was cumulative morphine consumption within 6 hours postoperatively. Secondary outcomes included pain scores, morphine pump activations, QoR-15 scores, and length of hospital stay. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using opaque envelopes. Blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Results: Of the 54 patients randomised, 27 were allocated to each group. ESPB resulted in significantly lower morphine consumption within 6 hours postoperatively compared to QLB (mean difference: 2.52 mg, 95% CI: 0.15–4.89; P=0.04). ESPB also led to lower early pain scores, fewer morphine pump activations, higher QoR-15 scores at 24 and 48 hours, and shorter hospital stays (P<0.05 for all). No block-related complications were observed in either group.

Interpretation: ESPB may offer superior early postoperative analgesia and recovery benefits compared to QLB in laparoscopic nephrectomy. These findings suggest that ESPB could be a valuable option for perioperative pain management in this surgical context. However, as an exploratory study with a limited sample size, further validation in larger populations is necessary.

Trial Registration: Chinese Clinical Trial Registry, ChiCTR2300074743.

Funding: Not specified.
